active_learning.discussion_prompt: Debate the challenges of implementing the Principle of Least Privilege (PoLP) in a large organization where usability is often prioritized over security. Provide real-world examples from breaches (e.g., SolarWinds or Colonial Pipeline) where privilege creep contributed to the incident, and propose balanced mitigation strategies.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in university-level pedagogy using Bloom's Taxonomy, active learning, and 4-layer scaffolding. Topic: Least Privilege Principle Implementation (Category: Cybersecurity > Asset Security > Data Security Controls > Access Control for Data > Authorization and Privilege Management). Incorporate this full content context: - Core Concepts: PoLP grants minimal necessary permissions; reduces attack surface; prevents privilege creep; includes JIT access and Zero Trust. - Best Practices (complete): 1. Default deny/low privileges. 2. RBAC roles. 3. JIT access. 4. Regular audits/reviews. 5. Monitoring/logging. 6. Automation. 7. User training. - Standards: NIST SP 800-53 (AC-6), CIS Controls (Control 6), OWASP guidelines. - Prior Knowledge: Authentication vs. Authorization. - Learning Objectives: [Insert the 6 objectives from above]. - Scaffolding: Generate exactly 10 flashcards per layer [Insert scaffolding descriptions]. - Active Learning Ties: Reference discussion on usability challenges, peer teaching on JIT/RBAC, problem-solving on privilege creep audits. Output 40-50 flashcards strictly following this schema per card: { "id": 1, "layer": "1", "blooms_level": "REMEMBER", "front": "MCQ question with A/B/C/D options...", "back": { "correct_answer": "A", "explanation": "Detailed explanation...", "references": ["NIST SP 800-53"], "active_learning_link": "Links to privilege creep scenario" } } Ensure high-quality: Questions test progressive complexity (foundation to integration). Distractors are plausible per protocol: 1 misconception, 1 related concept, 1 partial truth. Explanations scaffold learning and connect to objectives/activities. Output as a JSON array of objects.
